Package io.crums.sldg.packs

Class RecurseHashRowPack

java.lang.Object
io.crums.sldg.packs.RecurseHashRowPack
All Implemented Interfaces:
RowBag, io.crums.util.hash.Digest
Direct Known Subclasses:
RowPack, RowPackBuilder
public abstract class RecurseHashRowPack
extends java.lang.Object
implements RowBag
Recursive implementation of RowBag.rowHash(long) for a bag without redundant data.

Tautological Self-consistency

An important consequence of laying out row data this way (i.e. without redundancies) is that the data is collectively self-consistent. What this means is that given a RowPack with the correct number of hash entries, the individual hash entries don't need to be validated against each other: they collectively represent some ledger.

In retrospect, this observation is a bit obvious: aside from its trailed (witnessed) rows a skip ledger's rows can always be regenerated from scratch. A RowBag implemented this way, is much like regenerating a subset of a skip ledger from scratch.

    • rowHash

      public java.nio.ByteBuffer rowHash​(long rowNumber)
      Description copied from interface: RowBag
      Returns the row-hash for the row at the given number. The eligible input arguments are both from the full row numbers and also the row numbers of rows they reference.
      Specified by:
      rowHash in interface RowBag
      Parameters:
      rowNumber - a member of Ledger.coverage(getFullRowNumbers()) (note this includes row 0, where the sentinel hash must be returned)
      Returns:
      32-byte hash

    • refOnlyHash

      protected abstract java.nio.ByteBuffer refOnlyHash​(long rowNumber)
      Returns the ref-only row-hash from the minimal store, if found. A minimal bag does not redundantly contain row-hashes for rows for which their input-hashes are known: the row-hash of such rows can computed from the hash of the concatenation of the input hash with the row-hashes from lower numbered rows.
      Parameters:
      rowNumber -
      Returns:
